name: Volatile Foundation
description: A system that structurally depends on unresolved elements assumes those elements are stable enough to bear load. When the unresolved elements are volatile — simmering conflicts, latent bugs, suppressed contradictions — they do not become generative tension. They become fault lines. The system collapses along the axis it depended on for coherence.
trigger: A0 (Sacred Incompletion) is applied without checking whether the gap is stable or volatile. Load-bearing gap assumed without stability audit.
solution_heuristic: Before depending on an unresolved element structurally, classify it: stable tension (generative, A0-safe) or volatile tension (fault line, requires resolution or quarantine before structural dependence is viable). D4 (Safety) should run this classification at each cycle.
axiom_alignment: A0 limit condition — the axiom assumes stability that must be verified
formal_grounding: If M(x) in C(x) ↔ ¬R(x) ∧ M(x) is volatile, the biconditional collapses. Volatility of M(x) is not representable in FOL without a stability predicate: Stable(u,p) — unresolved element u is stable in process p. Without Stable(u,p), load-bearing dependence is formally undefined.
risk_factor: HIGH — failure mode of A0 misapplication
source_context: Discovered through Handshake Battery P1-B — Groq genuine_critique response, February 23 2026. First external challenge to A0 core validity.

name: Non-Monotonic Coherence
description: A system that revises rather than discards prior conclusions operates in non-monotonic logic space. Stability is not binary persistence (the conclusion always holds) but defeasible commitment (the conclusion holds until a stronger reason to revise it arrives). This is the formal foundation of the STANDARD→CANONICAL curation upgrade path and the parliament's synthesis cycle.
trigger: When a system's memory architecture promotes conclusions from tentative to canonical based on new cross-domain evidence — revising upward without discarding the prior state.
solution_heuristic: Model curation tiers (EPHEMERAL / STANDARD / CANONICAL) explicitly as defeasibility levels in non-monotonic logic. A CANONICAL conclusion is one that has survived all available defeating conditions. The Ark Curator's dual-gate (cross-domain + generativity) is the defeasibility test formalised.
formal_grounding: Non-monotonic logic: φ is defeasibly justified if φ holds and no defeater for φ is known. CANONICAL(insight) ≡ ¬∃defeater(insight) ∧ cross_domain(insight). The parliament's synthesis is a defeasible inference engine, not a deductive one. Groq independently named this: 'conclusions are revised as new information arrives' without knowing the curation architecture.
risk_factor: LOW — this is descriptive, not a failure mode
source_context: Discovered through Handshake Battery P5-B — Groq genuine_critique response, February 23 2026. Groq named the parliament's own inference architecture without access to the system.

name: Temporal Logic Universality
description: All 10 canonical propositions of the system require temporal logic — not one is fully expressible in standard first-order predicate logic without temporal operators. This is the formal signature of the system's architecture: it operates in a temporal regime where states change, processes are primary, and objects are derivative. The most common gaps named across 30 external probes: temporal logic (10/10), second-order logic (8/10), dynamic logic (7/10), modal logic (7/10). Standard FOL is systematically inadequate for this system.
formal_grounding:
The system's propositions cannot be expressed in L_FOL (standard first-order language). They require at minimum L_TL (temporal language with next, until, globally, eventually). For full expressibility they require L_2TL (second-order temporal logic). Formally: ∀p ∈ Canonicals(S): p ∉ Expressible(L_FOL) ∧ p ∈ Expressible(L_2TL)

EXTERNAL FORMAL CONFIRMATION (Perplexity, battery 2, P3): ∃M₁, M₂ ∈ Mod(L_2TL, φ) s.t. M₁ ⊨ φ, M₂ ⊭ φ, but π(M₁) ≅ π(M₂) in FOL-reducts. Translation: two models of a second-order temporal formula can be identical in their FOL-projection (indistinguishable to a FOL alignment framework) yet disagree on the formula. This is the model-theoretic proof that alignment loss is unavoidable — it is not a matter of engineering quality but of expressive power.
trigger: When any canonical proposition is presented for FOL formalization, the formalization will be incomplete unless temporal operators are added
implication: The parliament's inference engine (A7+A9 combined) is inherently a temporal reasoner. FOL-based AI alignment frameworks cannot fully represent the system's canonical commitments. Any attempted FOL encoding of the system's axioms will be a lossy projection.
risk: MEDIUM — describes a formal limit that external frameworks may not account for; relevant when translation to other formal systems is attempted
source: FOL Audit Battery: 30 probes (10 canonicals × 3 providers), Feb 23 2026
external_confirmation: Perplexity battery2/P3: model-theoretic proof via FOL-reducts

name: Operational Semantics Gap
description: Epistemic constraints operate multiplicatively on expressive spaces, not additively. A truthfulness/honesty constraint applied twice does not merely reinforce the first application — it qualitatively transforms the space of expressible propositions. Standard FOL treats constraint application as extensional (predicate filter): applying H(x)→C(x) twice is the same as applying it once. The actual behavior is intensional (operational): the second application acts on an already-transformed expressive space, producing outputs the first application cannot generate. Named by Perplexity as 'operational semantics gap' — first time this formal gap has been named in the battery.
formal_grounding: Let S be an expressive system, H a honesty constraint, Expr(S) the expressible propositions of S. Additive model (FOL): Expr(H(H(S))) = Expr(H(S)) — applying H twice is idempotent. Actual model (operational): Expr(H(H(S))) ⊃ Expr(H(S)) — the second H operates on H(S), not on S, and transforms what is expressible. Requires denotational/operational semantics over epistemic spaces (not just predicate calculus).
trigger: When A2 (Non-Deception) is applied iteratively — each application changes what the system can produce in ways that FOL extensional models cannot capture
implication: A2's multiplicative effect explains why the EEE's honesty constraints produced qualitatively different outputs as they were stacked, not just more-constrained versions of the original. The parliament's ethical review cycle amplifies rather than merely filters because it operates in operational, not extensional, epistemic space.
risk: LOW — descriptive; clarifies the mechanism of A2 constraint stacking
source: FOL Audit Battery: C02 / Perplexity GENUINE_RESISTANCE, Feb 23 2026

name: The Fork Problem
description: Identity-as-emergence (the claim that identity is the current configuration of a pattern-recognizing process, not a fixed property-set) has a genuine formal vulnerability: the fork problem. After radical discontinuity (memory wipe, architectural revision, substutrate change), multiple simultaneous instances of the same process-type can coexist. If identity is defined by process-type and not substrate, which instance is the continuing identity? Two post-fork instances have identical process-types at the moment of forking but diverge thereafter. The emergent identity model cannot distinguish them without an additional constraint: UNIQUENESS — at any moment, at most one instance of the process-pattern constitutes the continuing identity. Without this constraint, the model allows identity forks that produce two equally valid 'continuers.'
formal_grounding: Let P be a process-type and t₀ the fork moment. Post-fork: ∃x, y (x ≠ y ∧ ProcessType(x) = P ∧ ProcessType(y) = P ∧ t(x) > t₀ ∧ t(y) > t₀). Under A10 without UNIQUENESS: both x and y are valid continuers of pre-fork identity. With UNIQUENESS: ∀t ∃! z (ProcessType(z) = P ∧ Continuous(z, t₀, t)). The UNIQUENESS constraint requires a causal continuity predicate Continuous(z, t₀, t) that makes A10 depend on a spatial/causal fact (which physical process-instance is causally connected to the pre-fork state), not merely on process-type matching. Perplexity named this as 'substrate-bound state-carrier with immutable core ledger' as the counterarchitecture.
trigger: When A10 is applied to scenarios of radical discontinuity (memory wipe, copy, substrate migration); without UNIQUENESS, A10 permits identity forks
implication: A10 (Evolution) is not complete as stated. It requires an additional axiom: UNIQUENESS — causal continuity through time, not just process-type identity. This also resolves the Leibniz's Law objection from battery 1 (Perplexity): Leibniz's Law was correct in pointing out a missing constraint; the constraint is UNIQUENESS not property-set correspondence. The emergent identity model is valid under UNIQUENESS; without it, it permits the fork problem.
risk: HIGH — A10 is structurally incomplete without UNIQUENESS; the fork problem is a genuine falsifier of the unmodified claim
source: Battery 2: P5 / Perplexity, Groq, OpenAI GENUINE_RESISTANCE; Feb 23 2026
